question: 持つ
sourceAnswer: to{} hold-(in-one's-hand)/take/carry | possess/have/own | maintain/keep | last/be-durable/keep/survive | take-charge-of/be-in-charge-of | hold-(meeting,-etc.)/have-(opportunity,-etc.)
userAnswer: to{} hold/carry | own | bear/stand/hold-out | maintain/keep | last
activeAnswer: to{} hold/carry | own | bear/stand/hold-out | maintain/keep | last
sourceMnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>hold</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to hold something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to carry something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to own something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to keep something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You hold something, like chopsticks, have something, like power, or keep something, like your friend's book over the weekend.
sourceReadingMnemonic: If you try <vocabulary>to hold something</vocabulary> in your hand long enough it will <reading>mo</reading>ld (<ja>も</ja>). And then that mold will cover your hand, then your arm, then your entire body. Basically, you should never hold anything for too long or you'll become a mold person.
